Graphical abstract The displaying structural units of surface display system, including target protein, anchor protein and host cell, as well as two ways of the fusion between target protein and anchor protein. Sometimes histidine acid (HA) tag was added with the gene C terminal of target protein in order to purify the protein. The cell surface display technique allows for the expression of target proteins or peptides on the microbial cell surface by fusing an appropriate protein as an anchoring motif. Yeast display systems, such as Pichia pastoris, Yarowia lipolytica and Saccharomyces cerevisiae, are ideal, alternative and extensive display systems with the advantage of simple genetic manipulation and post-translational modification of expressed heterologous proteins. Engineered yeasts show high performance characteristics and variant utilizations. Herein, we comprehensively summarize the variant factors affecting lipase whole cell catalyst activity and display efficiency, including the structure and size of target proteins, screening anchor proteins, type and chain length of linkers, and the appropriate matching rules among the above-mentioned display units. Furthermore, we also address novel approaches to enhance stability and activity of recombinant lipases, such as VHb gene co-expression, multi-enzyme co-display technique, and the micro-environmental interference and self-assembly techniques. Finally, we represent the variety of applications of whole cell surface displayed lipases on yeast cells in non-aqueous phases, including synthesis of esters, PUFA enrichment, resolution of chiral drugs, organic synthesis and biofuels. We demonstrate that the lipase surface display technique is a powerful tool for functionalizing yeasts to serve as whole cell catalysts, and increasing interest is providing an impetus for broad application of this technique. Keywords Whole cell catalyst Lipase Surface display technique Yeast cell Application 1 Introduction (Triacylglycerol hydrolase, EC 3.1.1.3) are a class of versatile hydrolases with specific three-dimensional conformations. Many researches have demonstrated that lipases can catalyze the hydrolysis of triglycerides yielding glycerol and free fatty acids [1–3]. Lipases also can catalyze the transesterification and synthesis of esters as well as exhibit high chemo-, regio- and/or enantioselective properties [4]. Lipases displayed on the yeast cell as whole cell catalysts omit the tedious and time-consuming traditional purification and immobilization steps of lipases. Therefore, lipase whole cell catalysts have been widely used for a variety of applications such as biofuels, food, pharmaceuticals, and chemical synthesis [5]. The cell surface display technique allows for the expression of a target peptide or protein on the cell surface through linkage with a genetically fused anchor protein. Thereby, it combines gene expression, protein purification and enzyme immobilization. Fig. 1 shows the structural units of the surface display system, including the target protein, anchor protein and host cell, as well as N-terminal (target protein–anchor protein fusion) and C-terminal fusion (anchor protein–target protein fusion) methods. Occasionally, the histidine acid (HA) tag was added to the C terminal of the target protein for purification. This technique has been extensively used to develop whole cell catalysts, vaccines and antibodies, library screens, bioconversions, synthesis of valuable chemicals and bio-sorbents, etc. [6–8]. Yeast display systems including Pichia pastoris, Yarowia lipolytic, and Saccharomyces cerevisiae, are ideal, alternative and wide utilization display systems with many advantages including simple genetic manipulation and post-translational modification of the expressed target protein [9,10]. Engineered yeast expressing lipases show improved enzyme characteristics and considerable potential applications in organic synthesis [11,12], drug resolution [13] and bioenergy [14,15]. Table 1 summarizes numerous useful lipases successfully displayed on yeast cell surfaces for whole cell catalysis. It was demonstrated that the shifts of the displayed lipase conformation and activity depend on the features of the target protein, anchor protein, promoter and linker, which affect the exogenous protein display efficiency and post-translation modification and secretion [43]. From Table 1 it can be seen that more and more lipases have been successfully displayed on the yeast cell as whole cell catalysts with good stability and high activity [11,14]. Rapid advances in the life sciences, such as recombinant DNA techniques, have greatly increased the availability of whole cell catalysts. However, the matching of anchor protein, target enzyme, promoters and linkers is an important consideration in cell surface display development. In this review, we describe the recent progress on yeast cell surface display lipases as whole cell catalysts, focusing on the crucial factors affecting whole cell catalyst activity and stability. Then, a basic principle of lipase surface display on yeast cells is described. We also summarize some useful approaches for manipulating the stability and activity of recombinant lipases, including VHb gene co-expression, multi-lipase co-display methods, micro-environment regulation and self-assembly techniques. In the end, we elucidate the versatile applications of whole cell catalysts of lipase surface-displayed on yeast cells, such as the synthesis of esters, polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) enrichment, resolution of chiral drugs, organic synthesis and biofuels production. 2 Crucial factors of lipase whole cell catalyst displayed on yeast cells 2.1 Target protein conformation and molecular size Lipase activity is closely related to its conformation. In the lipase structure a lid of an α-helix, catalytic triad shelters the lipase active site, which commonly consists of three amino acids: Ser, His and Asp. The structure of lipase from Y. lipolytica (YlLip2) is given as an example in Fig. 2 . YlLip2 represents the typical α/β-fold in lipases with nine α-helices and eleven β-strands and a central β-sheet; it is made up of nine β-strands and five α-helices being packed on both sides of the sheet. The YlLip2 catalytic triad is composed of S162, H289 and D230 and an oxyanion hole. There is a lid formed by two small α-helices upon its stereo-structure, and it is observed that the C-terminal domain is closer to the catalytic triad than the N-terminal domain [44]. Factors affecting the lipase catalytic triad have a significant impact upon the protein post-transformation and modification, resulting in lipase activity [1]. Therefore, the molecular size and protein structure of the lipase significantly impacts the catalytic activity of lipases surface-displayed on the yeast cell. For instance, Sun et al. [45] reported that different activities of whole cell catalysts were obtained when different lipases were displayed on the yeast cell surface; the probable explanation is that the typological structure and flexible regions of the target protein were changed due to the interaction between the anchor and target proteins. When the anchor protein was proximally close to the active site of the lipase displayed on the yeast cell surface, the steric effect of the fusion protein affected the substrate binding to the active site. Fan et al. [46] demonstrated that lipase molecular weight generally affected the copy numbers of the fusion protein, resulting in variable activity of the whole cell catalyst based on surface display techniques, because the large fusion protein occupies a huge space on the cell surface yielding a low display level. 2.2 Promoter engineering In view of the surface display technique, the promoter greatly affects the activity of displayed lipases. Different promoters yield variable transformation and expression efficiency of the fusion protein, which is called promoter engineering [47–49]. Two types of promoters, constitutive promoters (GAP/GAPDH, GAL) and inducible promoters (AOX1, PGK, UPR-ICL, PHO5 and ADH1), have been used for lipase surface display on yeast cells. Patrick et al. [50] summarized the advantages and disadvantages of different promoters. Gera et al. [51] illustrated that expression of Aga1p and Aga2p was effectively monitored by the galactose-inducible GAL1 promoter, which could avoid the negative influence on cell growth so that protein expression was induced during cell growth. Recently, multi-promoter engineering has been widely investigated on lipase surface display techniques. For example, Duan et al. [52] stated that both AOX1 and FLD1 could be strongly expressed with induction by a low concentration of methanol (ca. 0.5%, v/v), and their co-promoter expression enhanced the efficiency of the fusion protein copy number. Table 1 shows that different promoters generate diverse expression level of fusion protein and variant lipase activity for the same target protein tested. The common strategy to increase the expression level of the fusion protein is to select a strong promoter. In view of the S. cerevisiae expression system, high lipase activity could be achieved using PGK as the promoter [53]. Liu et al. [37] constructed the recombinant promoter to display YlLip2 on the surface of S. cerevisiae with the highest activity at 7.6±0.4U/g dry cell. While for the P. pastoris expression system, GAP promoter is a more promising alternative than the AOX1 promoter. Zhao et al. [54] achieved a stable lipase activity of approximately 14,000U/mL using the GAP promoter in the P. pastoris expression system. However, the growth-phase-dependent HP4D promoter performed better for the Y. lipolytica expression system. Nicaud et al. [55] could achieve the lipase activity of 1000U/mL in 50mL flask scale when the lipase was surface displayed on Y. lipolytica using HP4D as promoter. Interestingly, if the promoters were incorrectly selected for lipase surface display on yeast cells over-expression or leakage of fusion proteins was always the result [16,21]. Therefore, multiple gene-promoter shuffling technology was carried out to screen some new strong promoters in industrial microbial breeding [56]. 2.3 Anchor protein type Screening an appropriate anchor protein is very essential for lipase surface display on yeast cells. Numerous anchor proteins are reported in the literature, such as Agα1, Aga1/Aga2, Flo1, Sed1p, Cwp1p, Cwp2p, Tip1p, Tir1p, Srp1p, Ycr89w and Pir [57], among which Agα1, Aga1/Aga2 and Flo1 are commonly investigated [58]. These anchor proteins belong to two categories, one is the C-terminal anchoring protein containing the agglutinin functional domain (N-terminal fusion with the target protein, e.g., Agα1, Aga1/Aga2, Cwp1p, Cwp2p and Sed1p), and the other is the N-terminal anchoring protein containing the flocculation functional domain (C-terminal fusion with the target protein, e.g., Flo1, Tip1p and Tir1p). An essential signal sequence was fused to the free terminus of the target protein to promote transport to the cell surface. When the anchor protein was fused with the lipase target protein, the primary structure of the lipase was rarely changed to sustain the stability of protein entire structure, but the topological structure (e.g. flexible region) was correspondingly transformed to facilitate the combination of the target and anchor proteins, including secondary structure transformation and active site shifts [59]. Tanaka et al. [60] suggested that the selection of an anchor protein depends on whether it is the S. cerevisiae, P. pastoris or Y. lipolytica cell display system. The S. cerevisiae surface display system, α-agglutinin, is frequently used as a N-terminal fusion anchor protein, and Aga2, Pir and Flo1p are widely employed for C-terminal fusion anchor proteins [61,16]. For P. pastoris surface display systems, the anchor proteins are generally derived from the S. cerevisiae cell surface. However, Lin et al. [30] recently identified 13 GPI-modified cell wall proteins coming from the P. pastoris GS115 as the anchor protein to display the target protein with high expression yields and considerable activity. In particular, the cell wall protein GCW61 showed a 21-fold and 238-fold higher expression level than Pir1 and Pir2, respectively, in the P. pastoris yeast display system, resulting CALB-Gcw61-expressing cells showed the highest lipase activity of 2234U/g dry cell. For Y. lipolytica surface displaying system, Jaafar et al. [62] successfully presented the isolation and characterization of the Ylcwp1 gene of Y. lipolytica and the homologously expressed GPI-CWP protein on the Y. lipolytica cell surface using Cwp1 from S. cerevisiae as the anchor protein. Yuzbasheva et al. [38] also reported the anchor proteins from Y. lipolytica cell surface to display YlLip2, and developed a C-terminal fusion lipase whole-cell catalyst, which had an activity (9170U/g dry cell) about three-fold higher than that (3200U/g dry cell) of the N-terminal fused lipase. Then, with genome analysis of Y. lipolytica, Yuzbasheva et al. [39] identified five putative open reading frames encoding glycosyl phosphatidylinositol-anchor proteins, and the highest activity (18,785±1130U/g dry cell) of YlLip2 was obtained using C-domains encoded by Ylcwp3 (YALI0D27214g), the activity exceeding lipase activity displayed on S. cerevisiae and P. pastoris surfaces. Jaafaret et al. [63] demonstrated that a lipase could be successfully surface displayed on Y. lipolytica cell using YlPir1 as the anchor protein through disulfide bonds with cell wall glycol-proteins. Protein-protein interactions are an important consideration when choosing the anchor protein, which greatly affects the total amount of target protein displaying and expression in the host strain. The fusion site between target and anchor proteins (N- or C-terminus) also significantly impacts the enzyme catalytic properties of the whole cell catalyst. For example, when the active site in the lipase structure is close to C-terminus domain, the C-terminus of the anchor proteins were used to display the lipase on the yeast cell surface. Otherwise, when the lipase active site structure is close to the N-terminal domain, the N-terminus of the anchor proteins were employed to display the lipase on the yeast cell surface [60]. Taking into consideration steric effects, the molecular size of the anchor protein showed obvious influences on the catalytic performance of the surface displayed lipase. Sato et al. [64] found that increasing the amino acid sequence length of the anchor protein could promote the accessibility to substrate and catalytic activity of the displayed lipase protein. However, anchor proteins with large molecular sizes could not improve substrate access to the displayed lipase [16]. 2.4 Type and chain length of linker The flexible linker plays a crucial action in lipases surface displayed on yeast cells. It links the target protein with the anchor protein to stretch the target protein outside of the host microorganism cell surface. The main function of the linker is to provide conformational flexibility with no alterations to molecular dynamics, which could decrease the effect on protein conformation caused by the matrix outside the cell wall [65,66]. The linker apparently separated the active site of the lipase from the anchor. It was demonstrated that the amino acids of the linker should be hydrophilic, flexible, easily folded, and contain smaller side chains. Gly, Ser, Pro, Ala, Glu, Lys and Thr, The (G4S) n , A(EAAAK)nA (n:2–5) and Gly/Ser-rich sequences were widely used as flexible linkers in the lipase surface display technique. It is very important to screen the optimal linker sequences for various fusion proteins because the type and chain length of linkers influences the displayed lipase activity [67]. Breinig et al. [68] reported that the insertion of a 350-residue Ser/Thr-rich linker in the fusion protein could dramatically increase accessibility to the target protein on yeast cell surfaces. FACS analysis further illustrated that 70% of the yeast cell population expressed the fusion protein. Liu et al. [37] demonstrated that the insertion of (G4S)3 linker between the lipase and the anchor protein improves the whole cell catalyst's lipase activity (7.6±0.4U/g dry cell). Washida et al. [69] evaluated the effects of the chain length of the linkers inserted between Rhizopus oryzae lipase and α-agglutinin anchor proteins on the whole cell catalytic activity. They found that the lipase whole cell activity was significantly dependent on the type and chain length of the linker for lipases with different structure and molecular size [66,67]. It was also found that the accessibility of the lipase catalytic active site to the substrate was related to the appropriate length of the linker for the whole-cell catalyst displayed on the yeast cell surface [60]. 2.5 Basic principles of lipase surface displayed on yeast cells for whole cell catalysis As is well known, surface display techniques include four structural units, namely the target enzyme, anchor protein, linker sequence and the host microbial cell. The reasonable combination of structural units is the key for successful lipase surface display on yeast cells. However, the matching principles of these structural units for the surface display technique and their impacts on lipase conformation and activity have not been well studied. Generally, when the catalytic active site of the lipase structure is located near its C-terminal domain, which indicates that C-terminal region is easily accessed by the substrate, the N-terminus of the lipase structure should be fused with the C-terminus of the anchor protein. The reasonable explanation is that steric effects between the target protein and the anchor protein would be reduced, and make the lipase to maintain the correct conformation, thus the whole cell catalyst would present high catalytic activity [60]. Similarly, when the catalytic active site of the lipase is located near its N-terminus, the C-terminus of the lipase structure should be fused with the N-terminus of the anchor protein. Under this condition, the N-terminal anchor protein should be chosen to obtain the high catalytic performance of the lipase displayed on the yeast cell surface. Furthermore, in order to achieve satisfactory catalytic activity, flexible linkers inserted in the fusion protein were necessary for the surface display technique. On the other hand, sometimes too strong of promoters did not facilitate the transformation and expression levels of the lipase displayed on the yeast cell surface due to “protein leakage”. Finally, the host strain cell is another key factor to consider when using the surface display technique. Although there were bottlenecks of hyper-mannosylation and low expression efficiency, S. cerevisiae was the most widely used as the host strain for the surface display technique [70]. Recently, some non-conventional yeasts, such as P. pastoris, Y. lipolytica, Hansenula polymorpha and Kluyvero myceslactis, have been developed as surface displaying systems [41,31,71]. It was worthily noted that P. pastoris is preferable as a surface display system because of little hyper-mannosylation, good suitable for secretion of high molecular weight proteins and low amounts of unwanted endogenous proteins [60]. However, considering the safety and toxicity of the host strain, Y. lipolytica shows more merits as a protein surface display system with great industrial potential applications [72–75]. With the development of gene engineering technology, it is very likely that more lipases will be displayed on yeast cell surfaces with high expression levels and activity in the near future. 3 Approaches to manipulate the stability and activity of the lipase whole cell catalyst 3.1 VHb gene co-expression Through strong promoter screening [53–55], chaperone and protein co-expression [76], codon optimization [77], and protein directed evolution [78,79], the enzyme performance of whole cell catalysts surface displayed on yeast cells could be improved, such as lipase stability and activity. Interestingly, co-expression of a lipase and VHb, the hemoglobin from bacterium Vitreoscilla (VHb), in P. pastoris could meet the extremely high oxygen demand for the methanol induced recombinant engineering strain, because the recombinant strain showed average oxygen association rate constants and high dissociation rate constants. Thus the co-expression technique of VHb and the lipase could improve recombinant strain cell growth, protein synthesis, metabolite productivity, nitric oxide detoxification and stress resistance of the hosts [80–84]. Wang et al. [85] constructed the co-expression recombinant of Y. lipolytica lipase (YlLip2) and Vitreoscilla hemoglobin gene VHb under the control of AOX1 promoter in P. pastoris. The results showed that the maximum YlLip2 activity in a 10-L fermenter was 33,000U/mL, approximately 1.84-fold higher than the control at lower DO levels. It was demonstrated that the co-expression of recombinant Lip2 and VHb gene obtained higher lipase activities and specific oxygen uptake rates, as well as cell viability in comparison with the YlLip2 single displaying on yeast cells under oxygen limiting and non-limiting conditions [85]. 3.2 Multi-lipase co-displayed technique Multi-lipase co-display technique is an alternative strategy to enhance the expression of target proteins on yeast cell surfaces. Whether the target proteins are fused with two independent vectors or a single one, the catalytic performance of co-displayed lipase proteins was better than that of a single lipase displayed on the yeast cell surface [86–88]. Yan et al. [34] reported a whole cell biocatalyst co-displaying lipases from Candida antarctic (CALB) and a lipase from Thermomyces lanuginosus (TLL) on the P. pastoris surface. The recombinant with two lipases showed a high activity of 623U/g dry cell, which was 7.3- and 2.4-fold higher than that of the single displayed CALB and TLL, respectively. However, time-consuming and the requirement of multiple selectable markers hinders the development of the co-display technique [89–91]. Sun et al. [92] constructed a co-displayed CALB recombinant system by self-processing foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) 2A. The co-displayed lipases possessed 170% hydrolytic activity and 155% synthetic activity compared to the single displayed CALB. It suggests that the self-processing FMDV2A peptide could improve catalytic properties of the lipase co-displayed on the P. pastoris cell surface, which would mediate two heterogeneous GPI-anchored fusion protein expressions into a single ORF. 3.3 Microenvironment interference technique Alterations to the microenvironment surrounding the lipase surface will influence the catalytic activity and promote the irreversible denaturation of lipases. An example is when the active water content and organic solvent concentrations are varied [93]. Thus, in view of transesterification of biodiesel production by lipase catalysts, a three-step addition of methanol is usually necessary [93,94]. For instance, Huang et al. [95] obtained the biodiesel yield of 83.14% by a three-step methanol addition. Hama et al. [17] developed a surface-displayed lipase from R. oryzae (ROL) by surfactant modification, and the modified whole cell catalyst showed good catalytic performance for organic synthesis reactions. Compared with the control, the Tween 20-modified catalyst could present 8–30-fold higher specific activity in organic solvents with relatively high log P values, and the nonionic surfactants modified surface display ROL could increase the enzyme specific activity in n-hexane. Therefore, pretreatment with organic solvents is an efficient procedure to enhance the activity of lipase whole cell catalysts displayed on yeast cell surfaces [96]. Recently, alterations to the microenvironment as a technique has been intensively studied to determine effects on the lipase conformation and activity. For example, biodiesel synthesis and conformation of Burlkholderia cepacia lipase (BCL) were investigated in 19 different room temperature ionic liquids (RTILs) in the range of cation and anion structure. The results showed that the effect of cation and anion structure of RTILs on lipase activity and conformation was significant, and the lipase showed highest activity in RTIL [OmPy][BF4] in our previous work [97]. Furthermore, the structure and activity of Candida rugosa lipase (CRL) in the pretreatment with 17 ionic liquids (ILs), five organic solvents and super-critical carbon dioxide (SC-CO2) was also studied [98]. It was revealed that the suitable reaction medium would facilitate CRL catalysis and transformation characteristics due to the changes of the CRL secondary structure in the pretreatment with ILs, organic solvents and SC-CO2 [98]. 3.4 Self-assembly technique Self-surface assembly has become a suitable method to increase the expression level and stability of target proteins. Lipases could be self-assembled by non-catalytic scaffoldin proteins through high-affinity interactions between scaffoldin-borne cohesins and enzyme-borne dockerins [99]. Fan et al. [46] established cell surface attachment of cellulosomes with two individual mini scaffoldins to promote the display yield. Recently, increasing attention has been focused on nano-/micro-polymeric particles with their appropriate properties to meet specific needs in various research fields [100]. Polymer particles such as PEGylation have promoted ease of surface modification, large surface areas, slow or fast polymer degradation and easy scale-up [101–103]. Sun et al. [104] reported that R. oryzae IFO 4697 whole cell catalyst assembled by glutaraldehyde (GA) cross-linking could enhance its stability and exhibit good catalytic activity, and it could maintain high catalytic activity after being recycled for fifteen batches because the cell produced a more dense film near the particle surface after GA cross-linking. 4 Applications of whole cell catalyst for lipase surface displayed in yeast cell 4.1 Synthesis of esters Compared to the native format, surface displayed lipases possess better thermal stability, organic solvent tolerance, and substrate affinity [18]. Lipases are frequently used to produce functional fatty acids, structural lipids and fatty acid esters due to their dominant properties in hydrolyzing triacylglycerols and catalyzing the synthesis of esters through esterification and transesterification. As shown in Table 2 , various lipases were successfully displayed on diverse yeast surface, and the whole cell catalysts were used to synthesize multiple esters such as fatty acid esters, flavor esters and sugar esters. The conversion yield of esters was as high as 98%. The surface display CALB has become one of the most important and efficient whole cell catalysts in the synthesis of esters [28,107–109]. Therefore, it is very important for us to successfully develop more and more efficient whole cell catalysts based on the surface display technique and strengthen its application to research in the future. 4.2 Organic synthesis Recently, considerable attention has been paid to whole-cell catalysis by lipases surface displayed on yeast cells for organic synthesis applications. This includes the biosynthesis of peptides, polymers and vitamin esters [110]. Using ROL as an example, Table 3 shows the synthesis of various vitamin esters catalyzed by surface-displayed lipases. This technique has been broadly applied to biosynthesize different organic compounds such as vitamin C linoleate, vitamin A palmitate, vitamin A lactate, vitamin E linoeate, vitamin E succinate and vitamin E oleate [117,118]. 4.3 PUFA enrichment Lipase from Geotrichum sp.(GSL) is outstanding for the selective hydrolysis of cis-9 unsaturated fatty acids including oleic, linoleic and α-linoleic acid. It is also effective for the enrichment of EPA (20:5-5c, 8c, 11c, 14c, 17c) and DHA (22:6-4c, 7c, 10c, 13c, 16c, 19c) fatty acids [119,120]. However, the bottleneck of GSL for large scale industrialization is primarily high cost and low stability of the free native format. To overcome these shortcomings, GSL whole cell catalysts surface displayed on yeast cells were successfully constructed, and was applied for the enrichment of EPA and DHA from fish oil [115]. The results showed that the fish oil hydrolysis rate by whole cell catalysts (40%) was higher than that of native GSL powder (12%), and whole cell catalysts maintained over 80% of their relative hydrolysis activity after five cycles. Pan et al. [25] reported that the GSL fused with alpha-agglutinin was successfully displayed on the P. pastoris cell surface, and the maximum olive oil hydrolysis activity of the whole cell catalyst reached 273±2.4U/g dry cell. This whole cell catalyst performed potential industrial applications in the enrichment of DHA and EPA with a total yield of 46.62%. 4.4 Resolution of chiral drugs The lipase-catalyzed stereo-chemical resolution of chiral drugs shows many advantages including high chemo-, regio- and/or enantio-selectivity. Table 4 summarizes chiral drug resolution by lipase whole cell catalysts surface-displayed on yeast cells. It was shown that ROL and CALB displayed on yeast cell surfaces could be alternative candidates in the catalysis of enantiomer resolution with desirable ee and EE values. Interestingly, the displayed ROL could catalyze the resolution of enantiomers in organic solvents, while native ROL powder was unable [31]. However, it is a challenge for us to lower the cost and enhance the activity of lipase whole cell catalysts displayed on yeast cell surfaces. 4.5 Biodiesel synthesis Biodiesel, a mixture of monoalkyl esters of long chain fatty acids (FAME) derived from renewable lipid sources, has attracted considerable attention as an environmentally friendly, alternative and biodegradable fuel [116]. Although there are many reports on enzymatic methods for biodiesel production from various feed stocks [121], information on lipases surface displayed on yeast cells as whole-cell catalysts for biodiesel production is limited. As illustrated in Table 5 , RML and ROL are the common lipases surface-displayed on yeast cells as whole cell catalysts for biodiesel production. Recombinant RML-surface displayed on P. pastoris was successfully employed for biodiesel production with a yield of 83.14% after 72h [95]. The combined utilization of CALB and RML, which were displayed on P. pastoris cells separately, possessed higher monoalkyl esters (ME) yields that exceeded 90% in 12h and retained desirable ME yields after 20 repeated batch cycles [22]. Qin et al. [119] reported that whole cells of Rhizopus chinensis were lyophilized and then used to produce biodiesel. Over 93% biodiesel yield was achieved under the optimal conditions. Hama et al. [120] evaluated the efficiency of lipase whole-cell catalysts in packed bed reactor systems, and it was demonstrated that the lipase whole cell catalyst showed high repeated utilization in packed bed reactors when a suitable circulation flow rate was monitored. In comparison with traditional enzyme catalysis, biodiesel synthesis by lipases displaying the whole cell catalyst offered a number of advantages such as cost-effective enzymes, low substrate consumption, mild reaction conditions and the method is environmentally friendly. 5 Conclusions and future prospects Due to the fast evolution of the alternative fuel and green chemistry industry, the surface display technique has been rapidly employed to develop whole cell catalysts, which possess the combination of enzyme purification and immobilization together. With high catalytic activities and stabilities, whole cell catalysts based on the surface display technique has been extensively applied in various fields including the synthesis of esters, PUFA enrichment, chiral drug resolution, organic synthesis and biodiesel production. This review shed highlights into the basic matching principles of displaying structural units (e.g. target enzyme, anchor protein, linker and the host microbial cell) in the surface display system to construct lipase whole cell catalysts for the first time. The review pointed out that the development of a wider variety of anchor proteins will be a promising way to broaden the applications of yeast cell surface display techniques. Additionally, the persistent research of new displaying yeast systems and collaboration of different surface display platforms are promising alternative solutions. However, low lipase activity and display efficiency has hindered this development. To be satisfactory, some novel strategies of VHb gene co-expression, multi-enzyme co-displayed technique, micro-environmental interference and self-assembly techniques have been employed. In conclusion, the yeast cell surface display technique is a powerful tool for development of lipase whole cell biocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: The cell surface display technique allows for the expression of target proteins or peptides on the microbial cell surface by fusing an appropriate protein as an anchoring motif. Yeast display systems, such as Pichia pastoris, Yarowia lipolytica and Saccharomyces cerevisiae, are ideal, alternative and extensive display systems with the advantage of simple genetic manipulation and post-translational modification of expressed heterologous proteins. Engineered yeasts show high performance characteristics and variant utilizations. Herein, we comprehensively summarize the variant factors affecting lipase whole cell catalyst activity and display efficiency, including the structure and size of target proteins, screening anchor proteins, type and chain length of linkers, and the appropriate matching rules among the above-mentioned display units. Furthermore, we also address novel approaches to enhance stability and activity of recombinant lipases, such as VHb gene co-expression, multi-enzyme co-display technique, and the micro-environmental interference and self-assembly techniques. Finally, we represent the variety of applications of whole cell surface displayed lipases on yeast cells in non-aqueous phases, including synthesis of esters, PUFA enrichment, resolution of chiral drugs, organic synthesis and biofuels. We demonstrate that the lipase surface display technique is a powerful tool for functionalizing yeasts to serve as whole cell catalysts, and increasing interest is providing an impetus for broad application of this technique.
coredata.dc:title: Yeast cell surface display for lipase whole cell catalyst and its applications
